title: Understanding Urticaria: Description, Symptoms, Causes, and Treatments

sections.title: DESCRIPTION
sections.content: Urticaria, also commonly known as hives, is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of raised, red, or pale, itchy welts on the skin. These welts are typically well-defined and vary in size from small bumps to large plaques. They can appear anywhere on the body, and individual welts typically last from minutes to hours before fading. In some cases, new welts may appear as older ones fade. Urticaria is characterised by very itchy weals (hives), with or without surrounding erythematous flares. The name urticaria is derived from the common European stinging nettle Urtica dioica. Urticaria can be acute or chronic, spontaneous or inducible. A weal (or wheal) is a superficial skin-coloured or pale skin swelling, usually surrounded by erythema that lasts anything from a few minutes to 24 hours. Urticaria can co-exist with angioedema which is a deeper swelling within the skin or mucous membranes.

features.details: Urticarial weals can be a few millimetres or several centimetres in diameter, coloured white or red, with or without a red flare. Each weal may last a few minutes or several hours and may change shape. Weals may be round, or form rings, a map-like pattern, or giant patches.
Angioedema is more often localised. It commonly affects the face (especially eyelids and perioral sites), hands, feet, and genitalia. It may involve tongue, uvula, soft palate, or larynx.

symptoms.details: The most common symptom is intense itching, which can be quite bothersome and disruptive.
The welts may appear red or pale, depending on the individual and the cause of the urticaria.
They are raised above the surrounding skin surface.
They can range from small bumps to large plaques.
Individual welts typically last minutes to hours before fading.
Swelling deeper in the skin, often affecting the face, lips, tongue, or genitals. Angioedema can cause difficulty breathing if it affects the airway.
These symptoms can occur if the urticaria involves the lining of the digestive tract.
This is less common but can occur in some cases.

sections.title: CAUSES
sections.description: Weals are due to release of chemical mediators from tissue mast cells and circulating basophils. These chemical mediators include histamine, platelet-activating factor and cytokines. The mediators activate sensory nerves and cause dilation of blood vessels and leakage of fluid into surrounding tissues. Bradykinin release causes angioedema. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain urticaria. The immune, arachidonic acid and coagulation systems are involved, and genetic mutations are under investigation.

causes.description: Involves an immune system response that triggers the release of histamine, leading to the development of welts.
common_triggers: Acute urticaria with fever can be the first sign of COVID-19 infection

causes.description: Not directly related to the immune system.
common_triggers: Serum sickness due to blood transfusion and serum sickness-like reactions due to certain drugs cause acute urticaria leaving bruises, fever, swollen lymph glands, joint pain and swelling.

treatments.description: Block the action of histamine, which is responsible for the symptoms of urticaria.
treatments.note: Mainstay of treatment for most cases of urticaria and are available over-the-counter and by prescription.

treatments.description: Can be used in severe cases of urticaria or when antihistamines are not effective.
treatments.note: Typically not recommended for long-term use due to potential side effects.

treatments.description: May be used depending on the cause of the urticaria.
Can help prevent future outbreaks if a specific trigger can be identified.
treatments.note: Triggers may include certain foods, medications, physical factors, or stress.

diagnostic.description: Urticaria is diagnosed in people with a history of weals that last less than 24 hours with or without angioedema. A medication and family history should be elicited. A thorough physical examination should be undertaken.
Skin prick tests and radioallergosorbent tests (RAST) or CAP fluoroimmunoassay may be requested if a drug, latex, or food allergy is suspected in acute urticaria.
diagnostic.note: Typically not recommended for long-term use due to potential side effects.

diagnostic.description: There are no routine diagnostic tests in chronic spontaneous urticaria apart from blood count and C-reactive protein (CBC, CRP), but investigations may be undertaken if an underlying disorder is suspected

The autologous serum skin test is sometimes carried out in chronic spontaneous urticaria, but its value is uncertain. It is positive if an injection of the patient's serum under the skin causes a red weal.
Inducible urticaria is often confirmed by inducing the reaction eg, scratching the skin in dermographism or applying an ice cube in suspected cold urticaria.

Investigations for a systemic condition or autoinflammatory disease should be undertaken in urticaria patients with fever, joint or bone pain, and malaise. Patients with angioedema without weals should be asked if they take ACE inhibitor drugs and tested for complement C4; C1-INH levels, function and antibodies; and C1q.

Biopsy of urticaria can be non-specific. The pathology shows oedema in the dermis and dilated blood vessels, with a variable mixed inflammatory infiltrate. Vessel-wall damage indicates urticarial vasculitis.

outlook.description: Acute urticaria resolves in hours to days but is often recurrent. Although chronic urticaria clears up in most cases, 15% continue to have wealing at least twice weekly after two years
